3.22.text: it can be hard to avoid the fear that we may

6.42.text: - and this might explain certain relationship hiccups -

9.52.text: be really quite bad in bed. 3 anxieties tend to predominate:

14.44.text: that our bodies are not attractive enough

16.44.text: that we don't practice or know about certain positions

19.48.text: and that we tire too easily.

21.96.text: These fears reflect an underlying view

24.28.text: that sex is predominantly an athletic or aerobic activity

28.96.text: and that therefore good sex must hinge on a capacity to flex our bodies optimally

34.74.text: but this risks misunderstanding what lies at the core of eroticism

40.02.text: for those sex traditionally makes use of our bodies. Sexual pleasure

43.80.text: may more accurately be thought of as stemming from certain maneuvers of the mind.

48.48.text: As new technology is showing us

50.48.text: it's quite possible for two people to generate extraordinary eroticism

54.88.text: while their bodies are a continent, or more, apart.

58.06.text: That's because eroticism is in truth about something else entirely:

64.24.text: Being a good lover is first and foremost a skill of the mind.

69.06.text: Sex grows pleasurable the more it functions as a release

72.12.text: from a great many of the ideas of what is normal that dominate in non-sexual life.

78.08.text: Good sex allows us to admit to and share

82.06.text: a maximal amount of what we must normally keep hidden

85.70.text: In good sex we will for example be allowed to show that we were

89.78.text: more interested in controlling and dominating someone than we normally let on

93.88.text: or conversely that we're very keen to submit and be entirely weak

97.96.text: We might want to subvert the hierarchies of normal life by exploring scenarios of

103.70.text: pilots and cabin attendants, professors and students, patients and doctors.

109.10.text: We might confess that, though monogamous by nature,

112.08.text: the idea of other people watching us or joining us excites us really rather a lot

117.20.text: or we may reveal that are erotic interests don't actually

120.38.text: - as they're meant to - circle exclusively around genitals that we're

123.98.text: really pretty interested in more incidental things like wrists or

130.52.text: We might be brave enough to challenge the normal chronological rules

134.24.text: revealing that we like to spend

135.76.text: a hugely long time with our clothes still on

137.98.text: or indeed rush straight in without decorum.

142.08.text: Sexiness is the excitement of feeling released from

145.70.text: the restrictive taboos of the rest of our lives

148.70.text: It's a safe mutually caring place where we can take someone else into the not

153.02.text: entirely responsible somewhat cruel and mad sides of us

158.16.text: that someone gives us permission to do this

160.48.text: that is at the core of what sexiness is. The person who is good in bed

165.90.text: therefore isn't the one who knows how to articulate themselves rhythmically for extended periods,

170.94.text: it's the person who encourages, endorses and legitimates our secret lonely selves

176.60.text: at the same time as being very aware of,

179.22.text: and honest about, their own private wishes and enthusiasms.

182.78.text: It's about a mutual nakedness of the mind, made possible through trust.
